Award.AwardTitle: Conferences in Formal Power Series and Algebraic Combinatorics, 2015 and 2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide support for US participants, especially women, graduate students, postdocs, and junior faculty, to attend the twenty-seventh and twenty-eighth international conferences in Formal Power Series and Algebraic Combinatorics (FPSAC). The 2015 edition will be held in Daejeon, South Korea, on July 6-10, 2015 (more info on the website http://fpsac.combinatorics.kr/). The 2016 edition will be held in Vancouver, Canada, on July 4-8, 2016 (more info on the website https://sites.google.com/site/fpsac2016/).

The most important annual conference series in algebraic combinatorics in the world, FPSAC offers young American researchers a unique opportunity to interact closely with top mathematicians from many countries. Somewhat interdisciplinary, the conferences link research in combinatorics to other topics in pure mathematics such as algebraic geometry, commutative algebra, representation theory, K-theory and symplectic geometry, and to topics in other sciences such as computer science, physics, and biology. Each conference, which includes nine one-hour plenary lectures, thirty half-hour contributed talks, and forty posters, will attract over 200 participants from all over the world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The FPSAC conference series focuses on algebraic and enumerative combinatorics and connections between these topics, other areas of mathematics, computer science, bioinformatics, and physics. Arguably the most important conferences in the world for the presentation of advances in algebraic and enumerative combinatorics, FPSAC’s one-week annual meetings attract top mathematicians from many countries, and offer young researchers a unique opportunity to interact closely with them.

In July 6-10 of 2015, the twenty-seventh international Conference on Formal Power Series and Algebraic Combinatorics (FPSAC) was held in Daejeon
(South Korea). The conference, which included nine one-hour plenary lectures, thirty half-hour contributed talks, and forty posters, attracted over 200 participants from all over the world. This award financially supported 32 young researchers, allowing them to attend the conference and in some cases present their research.

In July 4-8 of 2016, the twenty-eighth international Conference on Formal Power Series and Algebraic Combinatorics (FPSAC) was held in Vancouver
(Canada). The conference included nine one-hour plenary lectures, 27 half-hour contributed talks, and 75 posters. There were 161 submissions, and 230 registered participants from all over the world. This NSF award alone financially supported 29 young researchers.

In July 16-20 of 2018, the thirtieth international Conference on Formal Power Series and Algebraic Combinatorics (FPSAC) was held at Dartmouth College in Hanover, NH. The conference included nine one-hour plenary lectures, 27 half-hour contributed talks, and 72 posters. There were 140 submissions, and 230 registered participants from all over the world.
The funds that were left in this NSF award after all FPSAC 2015 and 2016 eligible participants had been reimbursed were used to partially
reimburse lodging expenses and registration fees for some FPSAC 2018 invited speakers and young participants.
